forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
@tummychow The point here is that BURG is VERY experimental, largely UNdocumented (or mis-documented) and it is NOT (at the current status) suitable to the less experienced members. The configuration file for BURG is /boot/burg/burg.cfg: [http://code.google.c...i/ManualInstall](http://code.google.com/p/burg/wiki/ManualInstall "External link") [http://code.google.c...rationVariables](http://code.google.com/p/burg/wiki/ConfigurationVariables "External link") It's syntax is anyway very complex (or at least more complex than "normal" grub4dos one and at least as complex as GRUB2 one). Suggesting to a newbie, unaware of the "basics" is not - as I see it - the right way to go, right now if you use just grub4dos or Syslinux you have mostly the same possibilities as the ones BURG offers, at the most you may want to add to grub4dos or Syslinux GRUB2 (or grub24dos) chainloading. In my opinion, you simply haven't (yet :wink:) enough knowledge to be able to tackle this particuar bootloader directly, you need to take baby steps, and get familiar with the commonly used procedures and tools which are by now documented. What right now you have is a "fancy" or "curiosity" towards BURG (which is a good thing in itself ![:smiling9:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/smiling9.gif) ) that you won't be able to satisfy until you go all the way through the learning process of simpler and better documented tools. @sambul61 JFYI, ***bean*** is already member of this Forum, under the nick of **bean123** since 2008, and I am pretty sure that if he wants (and has the time) to post here, he can do it without anyone asking. BURG has anyway it's own dedicated Forum, which does comprises an English section: [http://www.burgloader.com/bbs/](http://www.burgloader.com/bbs/ "External link") so, there is no need to know Chinese to post there, and I am pretty sure that that forum was created in order to have all BURG related things posted there.

What I mean, you can look through Grub2 docs to better understand its config and the ways \& tools to generate \& manipulate it, since Burg has a similar approach to config. What holds you from installing Burg onto a disk image saved on your HD or Thumb, once you understand how to get \& change its config? Somehow ppl manage to learn dealing with Grub2 in Linux, nobody died yet. ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif)  

Look also at *Firadisk* and *WinVBlock* drivers that extend Grub4DOS capabilities in booting images - that's another approach to bypass existing G4D limitations when you need to. *VMLite Vboot* bootloader manages to extend G4D features in its own unique way. These are alternative to Burg use in Windows, but since Grub2 is a mainstream for Linux, learning Burg seems to work for both worlds.

forumNotes.author: pokemon1
forumNotes.content:
It can be done in USB stick but I have done it in Ubuntu OS. I am not aware of installing it via Windows.  

Steps to install burg in Ubuntu: [http://code.google.c...i/InstallUbuntu](http://code.google.com/p/burg/wiki/InstallUbuntu "External link")  

Once BURG is installed in host machine plugin USB stick and follow these steps;  
1.Open a terminal and type sudo su  
2.Type fdisk -l (and note which device is your USB)  
3.Type mkdir /mnt/USB \&\& mount /dev/sdx1 /mnt/USB (replacing x with your actual usb device)  
4.Type burg-install --force --no-floppy --root-directory=/mnt/USB /dev/sdx (replacing x with your actual USB device)  

Cheers,
